pages.title: ⍟ King of Pentacles ⍟
pages.text: King of the Chariot of Earth$(br)       $(m)∆$() Air of $(m)∇$() Earth

The King of Pentacles sits on a throne embellished with carvings of bulls. He holds the sign of his suit, a coin emblazoned with the pentagram.$(br)  His meditative demeanor, though with a hint of courage, displays his somewhat lethargic tendency.$(br)  Grapes and vines adorn his robe, symbolizing the fruits of nature, but also the wine of celebration and religion.$(br)  His castle sits behind him, a symbol of all he has built through his efforts and

determination.$(br)  Traditionally, the King of Pentacles is a master of wealth, self-discipline and control.$(br)  He is therefore very serious about material security, he is proud of his achievements and likes to boast his prized possessions and wealth.$(br)  He makes little effort to understand ideas which are beyond his scope. His preoccupation to his domain blinds him to what is beyond his reaches or what could

have been.$(br)  He does not seek out battle; he is more of a overseer, less of a conqueror. But he is not weak, or passive, he too has had to fight to achieve and protect his kingdom.$(br)  He is the elemental Earth become intelligible.$(br2)$(l)Divinatory meanings$()$(br)  Valor, realizing intelligence, sometimes mathematical gifts.$(br)  Sometimes signifies a person of importance and substance; someone successful, who loves

life, and will protect what they have.$(br)  Someone calm, but with deep understanding.$(br2)$(l)Reversed$()$(br)  Vice, weakness, corruption.$(br)  An upheaval in terms of fortune or work.$(br)  The desire for adventure or stimulation.
